message.content:
cs.IT, cs.NI, cs.SI, cs.LG, cs.MM

Reasoning: 
1. cs.IT (Information Theory): The paper deals with pilot contamination, which is a well-known problem in massive MIMO systems, and proposes a low-complexity algorithm to mitigate it. This falls under the purview of information theory.
2. cs.NI (Networking and Internet Architecture): The paper discusses a system based on Time Division Duplexing (TDD) and channel reciprocity, which are relevant to networking and internet architecture.
3. cs.SI (Social and Information Networks): The paper proposes supervised and unsupervised clustering algorithms to decompose the estimated Power Spread Function (PSF) and isolate the part corresponding to the desired user only. This could be relevant to social and information networks.
4. cs.LG (Machine Learning): The paper proposes a low-complexity algorithm that uses the received UL wideband pilot snapshots in an observation window comprising several coherence blocks (CBs) to obtain an estimate of the angle-delay Power Spread Function (PSF) of the received signal. This could be relevant to machine learning.
5. cs.MM (Multimedia): The paper proposes an effective low-complexity approximation/implementation of the Minimum Mean Squared Error (MMSE) smoothing filter, which could be relevant to multimedia applications.
